Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial Comparing Free Dermal Fat Graft and Superficial Musculoaponeurotic System Flap in Superficial Parotidectomy

Trial_Design.evidence: Sample size was calculated to detect differences in Frey’s syndrome incidence with 80% power and a 5% significance level.

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a single centre, this prospective study included 78 adult patients undergoing superficial conservative parotidectomy for benign indications.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into two equal groups using a closed envelope method: one group received FDFG, and the other received SMAS flap.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial aimed to compare the effectiveness of free dermal fat graft (FDFG) and superficial musculoaponeurotic system (SMAS) flap in reducing these complications.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the development of Frey’s syndrome, assessed at 6 months postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was concealed, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Blinding.evidence: Randomisation was concealed, and outcome assessors were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Between February 2016 and October 2021, 78 patients were randomised equally.

Result_Outcome.evidence: There was no significant difference in the incidence of Frey’s syndrome between the FDFG and SMAS groups.

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were minimal, with mild infection and seroma occurring only in the FDFG group.
